choices.A: It establishes targeted LDP sessions between neighbors that are directly connected.
choices.C: It reserves bandwidth for LDP sessions between routers participating in a Cisco MPLS TE.
choices.B: It signals to LDP protocol along the path that a Cisco MPLS TE will be configured.
choices.D: It reserves the bandwidth along the path between the head-end and tail-end router.

questions.question_text: Which function does RSVP perform in a Cisco MPLS TE environment?

A network operator working for a private outsourcing company with an employee id: 4261:72:778 needs to limit the malicious traffic on their network. Which configuration must the engineer use to implement URPF loose mode on the GigabitEthernet0/1 interface?

choices.A: router(config)# interface gigabitethernet0/1 router(config-if)# ip address 192.168.200.1 255.255.255.0 router(config-if)# ip verify unicast source reachable-via any router(config-if)# ipv6 address 2001:DB8:1::1/96 router(config-if)# ipv6 verify unicast source reachable-via any
choices.D: router(config)# interface gigabitethernet0/1 router(config-if)# ip address 192.168.200.1 255.255.255.0 router(config-if)# ip verify unicast source reachable-via any router(config-if)# ipv6 address 2001:DB8:1::1/96 router(config-if)# ipv6 verify unicast source reachable-via rx
choices.C: router(config)# interface gigabitethernet0/1 router(config if)# ip address 192.168.200.1 255.255.255.0 router(config-if)# ip verify unicast source reachable-via rx router(config-if)# ipv6 address 2001:DB8:1::1/96 router(config-if)# ipv6 verify unicast source reachable-via any
choices.B: router(config)# interface gigabitethernet0/1 router(config-if)# ip address 192.168.200.1 255.255.255.0 router(config-if)# ip verify unicast source reachable-via rx router(config-if)# ipv6 address 2001:DB8:1::1/96 router(config-if)# ipv6 verify unicast source reachable-via rx

discussion.content:
“reachable-via any” must be configured for Loose mode on both IPv4 & IPv6.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/sec_data_urpf/configuration/xe-3s/sec-dataurpf-xe-3s-book/sec-unicast-rpf-loose-mode.html

questions.question_text: Which type of attack is an application attack?

discussion.content: C - HTTP is an application layer protocol, the only one possible choice here
ICPM and SYN operates on lower OSI layers, only HTTP works with OSI layer 7

Drop packets = Policing

Comparison of Shaping and Policing

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/quality-of-service-qos/qos-policing/19645-policevsshape.html

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A network engineer observed congestion between routers R1 and R4, which are connected on a point-to-point link. Two servers that reside on networks on R1 and R4 generate heavy traffic between them with most traffic going from R4 to R1. To improve overall performance, the engineer wants to drop inbound packets that exceed a configured threshold, without disrupting traffic that passes from R4 to R3. Which action must the engineer take to resolve the issue?

choices.B: Implement FIFO to queue excess traffic for transmission when bandwidth is available.
choices.D: Implement a service policy in the outbound direction on each interface on the link to tag traffic exiting each router.
choices.C: Implement traffic shaping to drop excess packets.
choices.A: Implement traffic policing to drop packets that exceed the given threshold.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I read it as...
B and C - why match dscp value in the same class map that sets them...?
D - doesn't make sense to remove dscp values.
It only said QOS Config for IPv6, and A only talks about v6. The rest included v4 so A is the answer.

Wow, such a confusing question! 
Probably A by process of elimination
In the configuration are no matches in the class for CM-10 or CM-20 but then they are only asking about IPv6 QoS so any answer relating to the IPv4 or DSCP 4 should not be correct. 

That leaves A, to create an IPv6 access list and apply that to CM-20.
ipv4 policy is already there so only need to add ipv6

choices.A: Create an access list that includes any IPv6 traffic and apply it to CM-20.
choices.B: Create access list IPv6-match and configure match ip dscp 4 and match ip dscp 6 in class maps CM-10 and CM-20.
choices.C: Configure match ip dscp 4 in class map CM-10 and match ip dscp 6 in class map CM-20.
choices.D: Create access list IPv6-filter and remove DSCP value 4 and 6 in class maps CM-10 and CM-20.
